sections.title: Critical safety alert
sections.content:
Critical fluid and electrolyte imbalances require immediate medical intervention. Select emergency type for step-by-step professional protocols.

Severe electrolyte imbalances can cause cardiac arrest within minutes. Immediate intervention and continuous monitoring required.

steps.title: Pay Attention to Your Body
steps.subtitle: Notice signs like thirst, swelling, dizziness, or fatigue. Keep an eye on how often you pee and its color. Sudden weight changes can mean fluid changes.

steps.title: Drink Enough Fluids
steps.subtitle: Drink water regularly, especially in heat or when active. If you’re sick with vomiting or diarrhea, increase fluids. Don’t wait until you feel very thirsty.

steps.title: Avoid Too Much Fluid
steps.subtitle: Drinking too much water can also be a problem. Swelling in feet, hands, or shortness of breath are warning signs. Balance is key—not too little, not too much.

steps.title: Replace Lost Minerals
steps.subtitle: When you sweat a lot, you lose minerals like salt and potassium. Eat balanced meals with fruits, vegetables, and light salts. Sports drinks can help after heavy sweating (not all the time).

steps.title: Limit Excess Minerals
steps.subtitle: Too much salt or supplements can stress your body. Follow food labels and don’t overuse electrolyte drinks. Only take mineral supplements if advised.

steps.title: Know When to Get Help
steps.subtitle: Seek help if symptoms are severe or don’t improve. Confusion, chest discomfort, or extreme weakness need attention. Children and teens especially need proper hydration.
